body: Trying to keep up with beta releases of Chrome is a massive amount of work, it is not at all as straightforward as bumping a version number. Tracking release versions of Chrome is already a daunting task, and we don't have the resources to keep up with beta

> Unfortunately, without guidance I cannot do anything because I lack knowledge of the compilation process.

You may want to check out https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/development/upgrading-chrome.md for a high-level overview if you want to try upgrading now to 58 and see what happens.

Thanks. Will check that.
Why do you say keeping up to date with beta Chrome releases is a massive
amount of work? Which is the difference between staying up to date with
stable chrome versions? You will have to upgrade sooner or later...

@kevinsawicki Thanks for the guide, but unfortunately I'm having issues, as not clear enough in which order I need to complete the steps from that guide...
Would love to have a clearer guide for newbies, as I'm trying to help also, but basically you just tell me "it's too difficult" and that's it.

Can you please help me with the following?

- Do I have to download chromium myself specified in VERSION file? Where should I put it?
- I cannot find the script `libchromiumcontent/src/tools/clang/scripts/update.py`. In which project does the file reside? electron, libchromiumcontent or chromium?
- There isn't even a Node.js version using v8 version that uses Chrome 58.0.3018.3. From the logs I found out that version of Chrome is using v8 5.8.244 and latest Node.js v7.6.0 uses v8 5.5.372.40.
Can I even proceed with the build process of v8 version must match exactly the one Chromium is using?

Thanks.

> Do I have to download chromium myself specified in VERSION file? Where should I put it?

No, once you edit that file and boostrap/build, it will be downloaded.

> I cannot find the script libchromiumcontent/src/tools/clang/scripts/update.py. In which project does the file reside? electron, libchromiumcontent or chromium?

This file will exist after chrome is downloaded, it resides in chrome, https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/tools/clang/scripts/update.py

> There isn't even a Node.js version using v8 version that uses Chrome 58.0.3018.3. From the logs I found out that version of Chrome is using v8 5.8.244 and latest Node.js v7.6.0 uses v8 5.5.372.40.

Yeah, this is one of the challenges when upgrading is to get a node version compatible with the v8 version in Chrome, node may still compile and work fine though against v8 5.8.

I assume much of the source code have changed, but how to know which patch is really needed for my use case? I just want a plain working chromium build :/

Thanks.

> What should I do when patches fail to apply?

The patches need to be updated so they cleanly apply against the new Chrome version.
The easiest way is to apply them to the Chrome source tree for that version and then recreate them with the updated SHA-1 information.

> I assume much of the source code have changed, but how to know which patch is really needed for my use case?

Most patches are needed to get Electron compiling since they expose or tweak APIs that Electron ends up using.

> The easiest way is to apply them to the Chrome source tree for that version and then recreate them with the updated SHA-1 information.

So if you have a Chrome checkout for the version you are upgrading to, you can run:

* `git apply path/to/libcc/patches/foo.patch`
* `git diff > path/to/libcc/patches/foo.patch`

This would apply then re-generate the patch, you may have to resolve conflicts after the first step.

I came back from holidays and now I'm trying to build Electron with Chrome 58 but I got stuck again.

I managed to apply/fix and re-generate patches for Chrome 58, but now I'm not sure how to proceed with v8/third_party patches.
I cannot find v8 source code inside chromium, it magically appears inside `libchromiumcontent/src` folder and I would like to fix v8 patches by applying them using git. How can I clone the specific v8 version that chromium uses?

If this works, I'll be happy to send a PR!

Thanks.

>  How can I clone the specific v8 version that chromium uses?

Following the build instructions for your platform should produce a full chrome checkout with all the proper versions of third party libraries.

https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/mac_build_instructions.md

Sure, but how can I just checkout the specific tag using those tools? I just cloned the full repo, checked out tag 58.0.3018.3, but dependencies are out of sync and I don't know how to proceed.
`gclient sync` produces the following error:

Only third_party patches are missing.

> Sure, but how can I just checkout the specific tag using those tools?

`gclient sync --revision src@58.0.3018.3`
@demian85 you may also want to try with the `--with_branch_heads` option.

```
gclient sync --revision src@58.0.3018.3
```
